content: What is the recommended prerequisite for this tutorial?
Completing the Getting Started tutorial, especially for new ROS and Navigation2 users.
What toolbox is used in this tutorial for SLAM?
What is the command to install SLAM Toolbox?
sudo apt install ros-<ros2-distro>-slam-toolbox or built from source in your workspace with: git clone https://github.com/SteveMacenski/slam_toolbox.git

What is the command to run Rviz and add topics to visualize?
Rviz and add the topics you want to visualize such as /map, /tf, /laserscan etc.
How do you request a goal through RViz or the ROS 2 CLI?
ros2 topic pub /goal_pose geometry_msgs/PoseStamped "{header: {stamp: {sec: 0}, frame_id:'map'}, pose: {position: {x: 0.2, y: 0.0, z: 0.0}, orientation: {w: 1.0}}}"
How do you save the map to file?
What launch file is used to enable SLAM as a launch configuration in the turtlebot3 getting started sandbox world?
tb3_simulation_launch.py with slam config set to true
What is the main purpose of the STVL costmap plugin?

The main purpose of the STVL costmap plugin is to buffer 3D data from depth cameras, sonars, lidars, and more into a sparse volumetric world model and remove voxels over time proportional with a sensor model and time-based expiration.
What is the benefit of using STVL in highly dynamic environments?
STVL decreases the resource utilization for 3D sensor processing by up to 2x.
How can STVL be installed in ROS 2?
STVL can be installed in ROS 2 via the ROS Build Farm or by building from source by cloning the repository into your Navigation2 workspace.
How do you load the STVL plugin in Navigation2?
To load the STVL plugin, a new plugin name and type must be added to the plugin_names and plugin_types variables inside of their respective costmaps.
What is the recommended visualization setting for RViz to visualize the underlying data structure's 3D grid?
It is recommended to set the PointCloud2Size to your voxel size and the style to Boxes with a neutral color for best visualization.
What is the purpose of the stvl_layer configuration in the nav2_params.yaml file?
The stvl_layer configuration is used to add the configuration of the STVL layer under the namespace stvl_layer.
Can pluginlib plugins for other Navigation2 servers be set in the same way as STVL?
Yes, pluginlib plugins for other Navigation2 servers such as planning, behavior, and control can be set in the same way as STVL.

What is the main goal of the Navigation project?
To lower the barrier of entry of mobile robotics technology for all
What is the Navigation project based on?
The original Navigation Stack (Nav Stack) in ROS (1)
Who are the founders of the Navigation project?
How long has the Navigation project been used by researchers, educators, and industry?
What is the difference between Navigation and Navigation2?
Navigation2 builds on the success of Navigation but redesigns the framework to be more flexible
How can users contribute to the Navigation project?
By submitting issues, pull requests, and support
Who is the current leadership team of the Navigation project?
How can users contact the Navigation project team?
By emailing the project leader or emailing info@opennav.org
Where can users post tickets for bugs or open-source feature requests?
What community platform is available for Navigation 2 users?
What is the primary function of the Lifecycle node in Nav2?
The primary function of the Lifecycle node is to systematically manage the bringup and shutdown of the different nodes involved in the robot’s operation.
What is the purpose of the Lifecycle Manager in Nav2?
The Lifecycle Manager transitions the states of the Lifecycle nodes and provides greater control over the state of a system.
What are the primary states of a Lifecycle node?
The primary states of a Lifecycle node are Unconfigured, Inactive, Active, and Finalized.
Composition is a key component of nav2 task servers that was introduced to reduce the memory and CPU resources by putting multiple nodes in a single process.
How can you add a new Nav2 server to your system?
You can add a new Nav2 server to your system by using the launch files to compose different servers into a single process.
What is the purpose of error codes in Nav2?
Error codes are used to communicate failures in a systemic way, allowing for automatic aggregation into the responses of the navigation system to your application.
How do you propagate your server's error code to the rest of the system?
You can propagate your server's error code to the rest of the system by adding it to the nav2_params.yaml file.
What is the purpose of the error_code_id_names in the BT Navigator?
The error_code_id_names define what error codes to look for on the blackboard by the server, and the lowest error code of the sequence is then returned.
What is the purpose of the SmoothPathBT node?
The SmoothPathBT node is a behavior tree node that interacts with the smoother task server to smooth output paths from a path planner.
What are the core ports to note in the SmoothPathBT node?
The core ports to note are the unsmoothed_path input port and the smoothed_path output port.
What is required to use a smoother in your BT node?
To use a smoother in your BT node, you must first configure the smoother server itself to contain the smoother plugins of interest.
What is the purpose of specifying a smoother plugin?
Specifying a smoother plugin allows you to implement specific algorithms that you would like to use for smoothing.
What is the purpose of modifying your BT XML?
Modifying your BT XML allows you to use the smoother(s) in your behavior tree for navigation behavior.
What is the purpose of the smoother_id XML port?
The smoother_id XML port is used to specify the smoother plugin to use when multiple plugins are available.
What is the purpose of the nav2_params.yaml file?
The nav2_params.yaml file is used to configure the smoother server and specify the smoother plugins to use.
What is the purpose of the ComputePathToPose and SmoothPath XML tags?
The ComputePathToPose and SmoothPath XML tags are used to compute a path and smooth the path, respectively, in the behavior tree.
What is the purpose of the TryToResolveSmootherErrorCodes XML tag?
The TryToResolveSmootherErrorCodes XML tag is used to recover from smoother error codes and trigger system recoveries.

What is the default configuration file used when creating a dev container?
What happens when a dev container is rebuilt?
The container is destroyed and recreated.
What is the purpose of the onCreateCommand in the devcontainer.json file?
To initially colcon cache, clean, and build the overlay workspace for the project.
What is the purpose of the updateContentCommand in the devcontainer.json file?
To re-cleans and re-builds the same colcon workspace as before, but only for invalidated packages detected by colcon cache using the lockfiles initialized during the onCreateCommand.
What is the purpose of the postCreateCommand in the devcontainer.json file?
To make a last few tweaks to the user’s environment to improve the development experience.
How can you speed up the initial build of a dev container?
By pulling images layers from the builder stage and caching them.
What is the benefit of using a dev container?
It allows you to have the project’s dependencies, intellisense, linters, and other extensions pre-configured and ready to use.
What is the recommended practice for storing persistent data in a dev container?
To avoid storing any persistent data within the container, and instead utilize the project’s source directory, or a separate mounted volume.
How can you rebuild a dev container from scratch without caching from Docker?
By selecting the Remote-Containers: Rebuild Container Without Cache command.
A dev container is a Docker container that has all the tools and dependencies you need to develop the project.
Why should you use a Dev Container?
A dev container provides a common and consistent development environment, ensuring everyone on the team uses the same tools and dependencies.
What are the benefits of using a Dev Container?
It makes it easy to switch between projects, and is especially useful if you work on multiple projects that use different versions of the same tools and dependencies.
When you open the project in VS Code, it checks for the dev container configuration, launches the container, connects to it, and mounts your project folder inside the container.
What are the prerequisites to use Dev Containers?
The prerequisites are not explicitly listed in the given context, but it mentions the need to have VS Code and Docker.
How do you get started using Dev Containers?

Getting started is as simple as opening the project in VS Code and following the notification prompt to reopen the project in a container, or explicitly opening the command palette and selecting Remote-Containers: Reopen in Container.
What security concerns should you be aware of when using Dev Containers?
Dev containers can be a security concern as they can execute arbitrary code, so ensure you trust the workspaces and authors, and verify patches remain benign and do not introduce any malicious code.

What is the purpose of the Dockerfile in the context of ROS Docker containers?
The Dockerfile is a set of instructions for how to build an image to create some kind of environment to work in - and often contain applications to deploy in that environment.
What is the difference between a Docker image and a Docker container?
A Docker image is the built Dockerfile which can be used to create containers, while a Docker container is a self-contained, runnable instance of the Docker image.
What is the purpose of the CMD and ENTRYPOINT commands in a Dockerfile?
The CMD and ENTRYPOINT commands are used to specify the default command to run when a container is started, and can be used to run applications or trigger other events.
How do you open an interactive terminal session with a Docker container?
You can open an interactive terminal session with a Docker container using the -it flags, followed by the exec command to execute the command bash in the container.

What is the purpose of the DenoiseLayer plugin in the Nav2 project?
The DenoiseLayer plugin is used to remove sensor noise from the costmap, which creates false obstacles that prevent the robot from finding the best path on the map.
What are the requirements for running the DenoiseLayer tutorial?
It is assumed that ROS 2, Gazebo, and TurtleBot3 packages are installed or built locally, and the Nav2 project is also built locally.
How do you enable the DenoiseLayer plugin in the Costmap2D?
You can enable the DenoiseLayer plugin by adding "denoise_layer" to the "plugins" parameter in nav2_params.yaml.
What parameters should be defined for the DenoiseLayer plugin?
The DenoiseLayer plugin should have the following parameter defined: minimal_group_size.
How does the DenoiseLayer plugin process obstacle information in the costmap?

The DenoiseLayer plugin processes only obstacle information in the costmap, and values INSCRIBED_INFLATED_OBSTACLE, LETHAL_OBSTACLE, and optionally NO_INFORMATION will be interpreted as obstacle cell.
What happens to cells with an obstacle that are recognized as noise by the DenoiseLayer plugin?
If a cell with an obstacle is recognized as noise, it will be replaced by FREE_SPACE after processing.
How do you run the Nav2 stack after enabling the DenoiseLayer plugin?
After enabling the DenoiseLayer plugin, run the Nav2 stack as written in the Getting Started tutorial.
How does the DenoiseLayer plugin work?

The plugin is based on two algorithms, one that applies an erosion function to the costmap, and another that removes groups of adjacent obstacles if their total number is less than minimal_group_size.

Groot is the companion application of the BehaviorTree.CPP library used to create, edit, and visualize behavior trees.
Behavior Trees are a method of orchestrating task server logic across a complex navigation and autonomy stack, consisting of many nodes completing different tasks and controlling the flow of logic.
What types of nodes are there in Behavior Trees?
What is the purpose of the "palette" of nodes in Groot?
The palette of nodes provides Groot with a list of nodes it has access to and important metadata about them, such as their type and ports.
How can a Behavior Tree be displayed in Groot?
To display a Behavior Tree, the Groot executable must be started and pointed to the palette or index of Nav2/custom behavior tree nodes.
How can a Behavior Tree be modified in Groot?
A Behavior Tree can be modified by pulling in new nodes from the side panel, connecting nodes using a "drag and drop" motion, and changing metadata about selected nodes.
How can a custom node be added to a Behavior Tree in Groot?
A custom node can be added by clicking the orange marked icon, filling in the metadata, and exporting the new node to the palette.
What is the format of a BT configuration file in BehaviorTree.CPP?
The format is an XML file.
What is the purpose of the XML file in BehaviorTree.CPP?
The XML file is used to dynamically load the BT node plugins at run-time from the appropriate libraries mapped to their names.
What is the difference between Nav2 and Groot?
Nav2 is a navigation and autonomy stack, while Groot is a companion application for creating, editing, and visualizing behavior trees.
What is the new behavior-tree navigator plugin in Nav2?

The new behavior-tree navigator plugin in Nav2 is a customizable plugin that allows users to replace or add new navigator types. It exposes the navigator types as plugins that can be replaced or new navigator types added.
What is the purpose of the Collision Monitor in Nav2?
The Collision Monitor is a safety layer that operates independently of the Nav2 stack and ensures the robot controls collisions with near obstacles obtained from different sensors.
What is the effect of the recursive refinement of Smac and Simple Smoothers in Nav2?
The recursive refinement of Smac and Simple Smoothers in Nav2 helps decrease out-of-the-box over-smoothing, reducing paths closer to collision than probably ideal.
What is the new Simple Commander Python API in Nav2?
The new Simple Commander Python API in Nav2 allows users to receive OccupancyGrid messages from Nav2 and work with them natively in Python3, analogous to the C++ Costmap API.
What is the Savitzky-Golay Smoother in Nav2?
The Savitzky-Golay Smoother is a new smoother algorithm added to the smoother server plugin list in Nav2.
What is the purpose of the Publish Costmap Layers feature in Nav2?
The Publish Costmap Layers feature in Nav2 allows the nav2_costmap_2d package to publish out costmap data associated with each layer.
What is the new Model Predictive Path Integral Controller in Nav2?
The new Model Predictive Path Integral Controller in Nav2 is a predictive controller that uses a sampling-based approach to select optimal trajectories, optimizing between successive iterations.
What is the purpose of the Behavior Tree Uses Error Codes feature in Nav2?
The Behavior Tree Uses Error Codes feature in Nav2 adds three new condition nodes to check for error codes on the blackboard set by action BT nodes, allowing for more robust error handling.

The PipelineSequence control node re-ticks previous children when a child returns RUNNING.
What happens if a child returns FAILURE in a PipelineSequence?
All children will be halted and the parent node will also return FAILURE.
What is the purpose of the Recovery control node?
The Recovery control node links together an action and a recovery action, and returns SUCCESS if and only if the first child returns SUCCESS.
What happens if the first child returns FAILURE in a Recovery node?
The second child will be ticked.
What is the purpose of the RoundRobin control node?
The RoundRobin control node ticks its children in a round robin fashion until a child returns SUCCESS.
What happens if all children return FAILURE in a RoundRobin node?
The parent RoundRobin node will also return FAILURE.

What is the recommended value for the model_dtparameter in relation to the control frequency?
The model_dtparameter should be set to the duration of your control frequency. So if your control frequency is 20hz, this should be 0.05. However, you may also set it lower but not larger.
What is the purpose of the visualize parameter in the MPPI controller?
The visualize parameter is a useful debug instrument while tuning the system, but use sparingly as it slows compute time.
What is the recommended approach for tuning the Obstacle critic?

The recommended approach is to first create the appropriate obstacle critic behavior desirable in conjunction with the inflation layer parameters, and then adjust the weights of the Obstacle critic in conjunction with the costmap inflation radius and scale.
What is the relationship between the costmap configurations and the Obstacle critic configurations?

There exists a relationship between the costmap configurations and the Obstacle critic configurations, and care should be taken to select weights of the obstacle critic in conjunction with the costmap inflation radius and scale.
What is the purpose of the Path Align critic?
The Path Align critic incentivizes aligning with the global path, if relevant. It does not implement path following behavior.
What is the purpose of the Path Follow critic?
The Path Follow critic incentivizes making progress along the path. This is what drives the robot forward along the path.
What is the purpose of the Prefer Forward critic?
The Prefer Forward critic incentivizes moving in the forward direction, rather than reversing.
What is the purpose of the Twirling critic?
The Twirling critic penalizes unnecessary ‘twisting’ with holonomic vehicles. It adds a constraint on the rotation angle to keep it consistent.
What is the purpose of the Velocity Deadband critic?
The Velocity Deadband critic penalizes velocities that fall below the deadband threshold, helping to mitigate hardware limitations on certain platforms.

Nav2 is the professionally-supported successor of the ROS Navigation Stack, deploying the same kinds of technology powering Autonomous Vehicles brought down, optimized, and reworked for mobile and surface robotics.
Nav2 allows for mobile robots to navigate through complex environments to complete user-defined application tasks with nearly any class of robot kinematics.
What are the key features of Nav2?
Nav2 provides perception, planning, control, localization, visualization, and much more to build highly reliable autonomous systems.
Nav2 uses behavior trees to create customized and intelligent navigation behavior via orchestrating many independent modular servers.
What are the expected inputs to Nav2?
The expected inputs to Nav2 are TF transformations conforming to REP-105, a map source if utilizing the Static Costmap Layer, a BT XML file, and any relevant sensor data sources.
What types of robots does Nav2 support?
Nav2 supports all of the major robot types: holonomic, differential-drive, legged, and ackermann (car-like) base types.
What is the purpose of the task server in Nav2?
A task server can be used to compute a path, control effort, behavior, or any other navigation related task.
How do the separate servers communicate with the behavior tree in Nav2?

Can Nav2 be used for multiple tasks?
Yes, a robot may utilize potentially many different behavior trees to allow a robot to perform many types of unique and complex tasks.

What is the purpose of the navsat_transform node?
The navsat transform produces an odometry output with the position of the GPS in the map frame, which is ingested by the global EKF.
What is the main difference between a standalone GPS and a GPS with RTK (Real Time Kinematic Positioning) technology?
The main difference is that RTK can bring the accuracy of receivers down to 1cm, whereas standalone GPSs can have accuracies of 1-2 meters under excellent conditions and up to 10 meters.
What is the purpose of the ekf_filter_node_odom and ekf_filter_node_map nodes?

The ekf_filter_node_odom provides local odometry by fusing wheel odometry and IMU data, while the ekf_filter_node_map provides global odometry by fusing the local cartesian converted GPS coordinates, the wheel odometry, and the IMU data.
What is the purpose of the robot_localization package?
The robot_localization package is used for sensor fusion, and it features reconfigurable state estimation nodes that use Kalman Filters to fuse multiple sources of data.
What is the purpose of the nav2_gps_waypoint_follower_demo package?
The nav2_gps_waypoint_follower_demo package is used to demonstrate the capabilities of Nav2's GPS waypoint follower, and it provides a launch file to put everything together.
What is the purpose of the interactive_waypoint_follower node?
The interactive_waypoint_follower node is used to build an interactive interface that allows users to click on a map to make the robot navigate to the clicked location.
What is the purpose of the logged_waypoint_follower node?
The logged_waypoint_follower node is used to make the robot follow a set of predefined GPS waypoints that were previously logged using the waypoint logging tool.
What is the purpose of the KeepoutFilter plugin in the Nav2 project?
The KeepoutFilter plugin is used to define keep-out zones where robots cannot enter and preferred lanes for robots moving in industrial environments and warehouses.
What is the format of the filter mask file used by the KeepoutFilter plugin?
The filter mask file is a raster file with a PGM, PNG, or BMP format, accompanied by a YAML file containing metadata.
How is the lightness of each pixel on the filter mask interpreted by the KeepoutFilter plugin?

The lightness of each pixel on the filter mask is interpreted as an encoded information for the specific costmap filter, with 0 meaning black color and 255 meaning white color, and values in between indicating varying levels of occupancy.
What is the purpose of the Costmap Filter Info Publisher Server in the Nav2 project?
The Costmap Filter Info Publisher Server publishes meta-information, such as filter type or data conversion coefficients, in nav2_msgs/CostmapFilterInfo messages, which are used by costmap filters.
How is the KeepoutFilter plugin enabled in the Nav2 project?
The KeepoutFilter plugin is enabled by adding it to the plugins parameter in nav2_params.yaml, and configuring its parameters, such as filter_info_topic and mask_topic.
What is the difference between enabling the KeepoutFilter plugin for global_costmap and local_costmap?

Enabling the KeepoutFilter plugin for global_costmap only will cause the path planner to build plans bypassing keepout zones, while enabling it for local_costmap only will cause the robot to not enter keepout zones, but the path may still go through them.
How is the Nav2 stack run after configuring the KeepoutFilter plugin?
The Nav2 stack is run by launching the costmap_filter_info.launch.py file, which starts the Costmap Filter Info Publisher Server and Map Server, and enables the KeepoutFilter plugin.
What is the purpose of the Speed Filter in the Nav2 project?
The Speed Filter is designed to limit the maximum speed of robots in speed restriction areas marked on a map.
What is the format of the filter mask file used by the Speed Filter?
The filter mask file should be in PGM, PNG, or BMP format.
How are the OccupancyGrid values decoded in the Speed Filter?
The OccupancyGrid values are decoded using the formula: speed_limit = filter_mask_data * multiplier + base, where the values are linearly converted into a speed limit value.
What is the meaning of the decoded speed_limit value in the Speed Filter?

The decoded speed_limit value can have one of two meanings: a percentage of the maximum robot speed or a direct speed limit value. In this tutorial, the first type of speed restriction expressed in a percent from maximum robot speed is used.
How do you create a new filter mask for the Speed Filter?
Create a new image with a PGM/PNG/BMP format, copy the turtlebot3_world.pgm main map, and fill speed restricted areas with grey colors.
What is the purpose of the Costmap Filter Info Publisher Server?
The Costmap Filter Info Publisher Server publishes incoming meta-information, such as filter type or data conversion coefficients, in messages of nav2_msgs/CostmapFilterInfo type.
How do you enable the Speed Filter in the Nav2 project?
You can enable the Speed Filter plugin in Costmap2D by adding speed_filter to the plugins parameter in nav2_params.yaml.
What is the purpose of the speed_limit_topic parameter in the Controller Server?
The speed_limit_topic parameter is used to restrict the maximum speed of the robot when needed, and it should be set to the same value as the speed_filter plugin value.

What is ROS 2 and what is its role in Nav2?
ROS 2 is the core middleware used for Nav2, and it is essential to understand ROS 2 before continuing with Nav2.
What are action servers in ROS 2, and how are they used in Nav2?

Action servers are a common way to control long-running tasks like navigation, and in Nav2, they are used to communicate with the highest level Behavior Tree (BT) navigator through a NavigateToPose action message.
What is a Lifecycle Node, and how is it used in Nav2?

A Lifecycle Node is a node that contains state machine transitions for bringup and teardown of ROS 2 servers, and in Nav2, it is used extensively throughout the project, with all servers utilizing it.
What is a Behavior Tree, and how is it used in Nav2?
A Behavior Tree is a tree structure of tasks to be completed, and in Nav2, it is used to provide a formal structure for navigation logic, allowing for complex systems to be created and verified.
What are the different types of servers in Nav2, and what are their roles?

The four main action servers in Nav2 are the planner, behavior, smoother, and controller servers, each hosting a map of algorithm plugins to complete various tasks, such as computing a path, following a path, smoothing a path, and recovering from failures.
What is the role of the planner server in Nav2?
The planner server is responsible for computing a valid and potentially optimal path from the current pose to a goal pose, using a global environmental representation and sensor data.
What is the role of the controller server in Nav2?

The controller server is responsible for computing a valid control effort to follow the global plan, using a local environment representation to attempt to compute feasible control efforts for the base to follow.
What are the main components of navigation plugins?
Behavior-Tree Navigators, Costmap Layers, Costmap Filters, Controllers, Planners, Smoothers, Behaviors, Waypoint Task Executors, Goal Checkers, Progress Checkers, Behavior Tree Nodes

What is the main function of the planner server in Nav2?
The planner server is responsible for implementing algorithms that compute the robot’s path.
What type of robots are the planner plugins that work on the grid space best suited for?
Robots that can drive in any direction or rotate safely in place, such as circular differential and circular omnidirectional robots.
What is the purpose of the Smac Hybrid-A* planner plugin?

The Smac Hybrid-A* planner plugin is a highly optimized and fully reconfigurable Hybrid-A* implementation that supports arbitrary shaped ackermann and legged robots, and is suitable for high-speed robots that require careful navigation.
What is the default controller plugin in Nav2?
The default controller plugin is the DWB controller.
What type of robots can the DWB controller be used on?

The DWB controller can be used on circular or non-circular differential, and circular or non-circular omnidirectional robots, and can also be configured for ackerman and legged robots if given a TrajectoryGeneration plugin that considers the robot’s minimum curvature constraint.
What is the purpose of the TEB controller plugin?

The TEB controller plugin is an MPC time optimal controller that optimizes the robot’s trajectory based on its execution time, distance from obstacles, and feasibility with respect to the robot’s kinematic constraints.
What type of robots is the Regulated Pure Pursuit controller (RPP) suitable for?
The Regulated Pure Pursuit controller (RPP) is suitable for use with differential, ackermann, and legged robots, particularly service or industrial robots.
What is the Vector Pursuit Controller plugin used for?
The Vector Pursuit Controller plugin is used for high-speed path tracking and sharp turns, or when computation resources are limited, and can be used with differential, ackermann, and legged robots.
What is the purpose of the odometry system in robotics?
The odometry system provides a locally accurate estimate of a robot's pose and velocity based on its motion.
What are some common sources of odometry information?
IMU, LIDAR, RADAR, VIO, and wheel encoders.
What is the difference between IMU and wheel encoders in terms of drift?
IMUs drift over time, while wheel encoders drift over distance traveled.
What is the purpose of the odom frame and its transformation?
The odom frame and its transformation use a robot's odometry system to publish localization information that is continuous but becomes less accurate over time or distance.
What is the purpose of the map frame?
The map frame provides globally accurate information that is used to correct the odom frame.
What is required for Nav2 to work properly?
Nav2 requires the publishing of nav_msgs/Odometry messages and odom=>base_link transforms.
What information does the nav_msgs/Odometry message contain?
The nav_msgs/Odometry message contains estimates for the pose and velocity of the robot.
What is the purpose of the robot_localization package?
The robot_localization package is used to provide a fused and locally accurate smooth odometry information from the data provided by odometry sensor inputs.
How does the ekf_node work in the robot_localization package?
The ekf_node uses an Extended Kalman Filter to fuse odometry information and publish the odom=>base_link transform.
What is the purpose of the gazebo_ros_pkgs package?
The gazebo_ros_pkgs package is used to simulate odometry and control the robot with ROS 2 in Gazebo.
How do you add Gazebo plugins to a URDF file?
You add Gazebo plugins to a URDF file by adding a <gazebo> element and specifying the plugin filename and name.
What is the purpose of the sensor_msgs package in ROS?
The sensor_msgs package defines the common sensor interfaces to standardize the message formats of sensors and allow for easier interoperation between vendors.
What is the function of the static layer in the nav2_costmap_2d package?
The static layer represents the map section of the costmap, obtained from the messages published to the/map topic.
What is the purpose of the inflation layer in the nav2_costmap_2d package?
The inflation layer represents the added cost values around lethal obstacles such that the robot avoids navigating into obstacles due to the robot’s geometry.
What is the function of the obstacle layer in the nav2_costmap_2d package?
The obstacle layer includes the objects detected by sensors that publish either or both the LaserScan and PointCloud2 messages.
What is the function of the voxel layer in the nav2_costmap_2d package?
The voxel layer is similar to the obstacle layer such that it can use either or both the LaserScan and PointCloud2 sensor information but handles 3D data instead.
How is the costmap generated in the nav2_costmap_2d package?

The costmap is generated by integrating the different layers (static, obstacle, voxel, and inflation) through a plugin interface and then inflating using a user-specified inflation radius, if the inflation layer is enabled.
What is the purpose of the slam_toolbox package in ROS?
The slam_toolbox package is a set of tools and capabilities for 2D Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) in potentially massive maps with ROS2.
What is the function of the nav2_amcl package in ROS?
The nav2_amcl package implements Adaptive Monte Carlo Localization (AMCL) which estimates the position and orientation of the robot in a map.
What is the purpose of the Robot State Publisher package in ROS 2?

The Robot State Publisher package is used to publish all the necessary transforms that can be directly inferred from the geometry and structure of the robot, allowing for complex transformations to be handled automatically.
What is the Unified Robot Description Format (URDF)?

The Unified Robot Description Format (URDF) is an XML file that represents a robot model, used to build transformations trees related to the robot geometry, and also has other uses such as visualizing the robot model in RVIZ and defining physical properties for physics simulators.
What is the purpose of the base_footprint link in the URDF?

The base_footprint link is a virtual (non-physical) link that has no dimensions or collision areas, and its primary purpose is to enable various packages to determine the center of a robot projected to the ground.
What is the purpose of the joint element in the URDF?
The joint element describes the kinematic and dynamic properties between coordinate frames.
What is the purpose of the xacro:wheel macro in the URDF?
The xacro:wheel macro is used to define a block of code that will be repeated with differing parameters, making the code cleaner and avoiding repetition.
What is the purpose of the launch file in ROS 2?
The launch file is used by ROS 2 to bring up the necessary nodes for a package.
What is the purpose of the urdf_config.rviz file?
The urdf_config.rviz file is a configuration file that initializes RVIZ with the proper settings, allowing for the visualization of the robot model.
What is the purpose of the CMakeLists.txt file in the project root directory?
The CMakeLists.txt file is used to include the files created during the package installation process.
What is the purpose of the TF2 ROS package?
The TF2 ROS package is used to publish the transform tree of a robot, which defines the relations between different coordinate systems in terms of translation, rotation, and relative motion.
What are the two defined coordinate frames in the example of a simple robot?
The two defined coordinate frames are base_link and base_laser, corresponding to the center point of the mobile base and the center point of the laser, respectively.
What is the relationship between the base_link and base_laser coordinate frames?

The relationship between the base_link and base_laser coordinate frames is defined by a translational offset, where the laser is mounted 10cm forward and 20cm above the center point of the mobile base.
How is the relationship between the base_link and base_laser coordinate frames managed?
The relationship between the base_link and base_laser coordinate frames is managed using TF2, which allows for the definition and storage of the relationship between the two coordinate frames.
What is the purpose of the transform tree in TF2?
The transform tree in TF2 is used to define the relationships between different coordinate frames, allowing for the transformation of data between frames.
How is the transform tree created in the example of the simple robot?

The transform tree is created by defining two nodes, one for the base_link coordinate frame and one for the base_laser coordinate frame, and creating an edge between them with a transform that corresponds to the translational offset between the two frames.
What is the purpose of the static_transform_publisher tool in TF2?
The static_transform_publisher tool in TF2 is used to publish a static transformation between two coordinate frames.
What is the primary use of the footprint in Nav2?
The primary use of the footprint in Nav2 is to avoid collisions during planning.
How is the footprint set up in the global and local costmaps?
The footprint is set up using the footprint or robot_radius parameter.
What is the difference between the footprint and robot_radius parameters?
The footprint parameter defines the robot's 2D shape as an ordered vector of 2-D points, while the robot_radius parameter generates a circular footprint.
How do you visualize the footprint in RViz?

To visualize the footprint in RViz, click the add button, select the Polygon under the /local_costmap/published_footprint topic or /global_costmap/published_footprint topic, and set the fixed frame to odom or map.
What is the purpose of the static_transform_publisher in the guide?
The static_transform_publisher is used to publish the map=>odom transform as static, allowing for visualization of the footprint.
How do you configure the footprint of a robot in Nav2?
You can configure the footprint of a robot in Nav2 by modifying the footprint or robot_radius parameter in the nav2_params.yaml configuration file.
What is the significance of the footprint in Nav2's pathfinding algorithms?
The footprint plays a major role in Nav2's pathfinding algorithms, as it is used to avoid collisions during planning.
How do you launch Nav2 using the nav2_params.yaml configuration file?

You can launch Nav2 using the nav2_params.yaml configuration file by executing the ros2 launch nav2_bringup navigation_launch.py command with the params_file parameter set to the full path of the nav2_params.yaml file.
What is the purpose of the display.launch.py file?
The display.launch.py file is used to launch the robot state publisher, spawn the robot in Gazebo, and visualize the robot and its footprint in RViz.
What is the goal of the Nav2 Simple Commander API?
To provide a “navigation as a library” capability to Python3 users.
What does the Simple Commander API handle for the user?
All the ROS 2 and Action Server tasks.
What is the purpose of the while not nav.isTaskComplete() design?
To poll for changes in the navigation completion.
Can preempt commands of the same type be used with the Simple Commander?
Yes, but the user must explicitly cancel a current command and issue a new one if switching between different types of commands.
What is the purpose of the namespace field in the simple navigator constructor?
To support multi-robot applications or namespaced Nav2 launches.
What does the Costmap API provide?
A Python3 API for costmap 2d messages from the stack, providing basic conversion, get/set, and handling semantics.
What does the Footprint Collision Checker API provide?
A Python3 API for manipulating coordinates and calculating the cost of a Footprint in a given map.
Where can examples and demos of the Simple Commander API be found?
What is the purpose of the followWaypoints() example code?
To highlight the API functions available to the user for building simple autonomy applications.

What is the true value of the inflation layer in ROS Navigation / Nav2?
Creating a consistent potential field around the entire map.
Why is it recommended to increase the inflation layer cost scale and radius?
To adequately produce a smooth potential across the entire map, allowing the planner to give obstacles as wide of a berth as possible.
What is the difference between specifying a robot's shape as a geometric footprint or the radius of a circle encompassing the robot?

Specifying a geometric footprint allows planners and controllers to plan or create trajectories into tighter spaces, while specifying a radius assumes a circular shape and may limit planning capabilities.
What is the purpose of the Rotation Shim Controller?
To allow a robot to rotate in place before starting to track a holonomic path, making it easier to tune a controller plugin for path tracking.
Which planner plugin is recommended for non-circular robots with very limited compute?
What is the purpose of the cache_obstacle_heuristic option in Smac Planners?
To cache the heuristic to use between replannings to the same goal pose, increasing the speed of the planners significantly.
When is it recommended to enable the cache_obstacle_heuristic option?
Only when working in largely static environments when planning across large spaces to singular goals.
What is the purpose of the Costmap2D plugins?
To provide additional functionality, such as marking keepout zones, reducing or increasing robot speeds, and enabling or disabling binary topics.
How can the Costmap2D plugins be paired with the VectorObject server?
To use vectorized zones rather than map rastered zones.

What is the purpose of the Collision Monitor node?
The Collision Monitor node acts as a filter for the cmd_vel messages from the controller to avoid potential collisions.
What is the default configuration of the Collision Monitor node?
The Collision Monitor node is configured for usage with the Nav2 bringup package, running in parallel with the navigation_launch.py bringup script.
What is the purpose of the Velocity Smoother node?

The Velocity Smoother node is used to smooth the cmd_vel messages, but it needs to be configured to match the input velocity cmd_vel_in_topic parameter value of the Collision Monitor node, and the output velocity cmd_vel_out_topic parameter value should be the actual cmd_vel to fit the replacement.
How do you configure the Collision Monitor with Velocity Polygon type?

The steps to configure the Collision Monitor with Velocity Polygon type include setting up multiple polygons to cover the range of the robot's velocity limits, configuring the linear_min and linear_max parameters of the sub-polygons to the robot's linear velocity limits, and configuring the theta_min and theta_max parameters to the robot's angular velocity limits.
What is the purpose of the theta_min and theta_max parameters in the Velocity Polygon configuration?
The theta_min and theta_max parameters are used to specify the angular velocity limits of the robot.
How do you configure the Collision Monitor for a holonomic robot?

For holonomic robots, the holonomic property should be set to true, and the linear_min and linear_max parameters should cover the robot's resultant velocity limits, while the theta_min and theta_max parameters should cover the robot's angular velocity limits. Additionally, there will be 2 more parameters, direction_start_angle and direction_end_angle, to specify the resultant velocity direction.
What is the purpose of the direction_start_angle and direction_end_angle parameters in the holonomic robot configuration?
The direction_start_angle and direction_end_angle parameters are used to specify the resultant velocity direction of the holonomic robot.
The Docking Server is a general framework that can be used with arbitrary types of robots and docks to auto-dock them.
What are the plugins used in the Docking Server?

The plugins used are ChargingDock and NonChargingDock, which implement the dock specifics like detecting the pose of the dock using sensor data, how to detect when the robot is in contact with the dock, and when charging has successfully started.
What is the purpose of the Dock Database?

The Dock Database contains the set of docks in the environment, their instance types, and a set of shared plugins, which allows many instances to share the same plugin to save on memory and networking overhead.
How is the docking procedure accomplished?

The docking procedure is accomplished via plugins that implement the dock specifics, and the Docking Server uses the plugins to detect the pose of the dock, detect when the robot is in contact with the dock, and when charging has successfully started.

The SimpleChargingDock plugin provides an implementation with common options for detecting the dock's current pose, when the robot is charging, and when contact is made, and can be used for testing and realistic applications.
How is the docking server configured?

The docking server is configured by specifying the plugin for interacting with a dock, the locations of docks in the map, and other parameters such as the fixed frame, docking threshold, and maximum speed.
What is the Docking Action API?
The Docking Action API consists of two main modalities: using the dock database or specifying a dock to use in the action, and allows for docking and undocking actions to be performed.

The UndockRobot action is a simpler action that only requires the dock type if undocking is being called when the server's instance did not dock the robot, and contains no feedback and returns the success state and error code if a problem occurs.
What is the Rotation Shim Controller?

The Rotation Shim Controller is a plugin that helps create intuitive, rotate-in-place behavior for robots when starting to track a path, by rotating the robot in place towards the path heading before passing control to the primary controller.
What is the purpose of the Rotation Shim Controller?

The purpose of the Rotation Shim Controller is to provide a better starting point for the primary controller to start tracking a path, making tuning the controllers significantly easier and creating more intuitive results.
What is the Rotation Shim Controller most suitable for?
The Rotation Shim Controller is most suitable for robots that may rotate in place before beginning their path tracking task.
How does the Rotation Shim Controller work?

The Rotation Shim Controller checks the rough heading difference between the robot and a newly received path, and if within a threshold, it passes the request onto the primary controller to execute the task. If outside the threshold, it rotates the robot in place towards the path heading.
What are the parameters that dictate the conditions for the Rotation Shim Controller?
The parameters that dictate the conditions for the Rotation Shim Controller are angular_dist_threshold and max_angular_accel.
How do you configure the Rotation Shim Controller?

The Rotation Shim Controller is configured by adding it as a plugin for path tracking in the controller server, and setting its internal parameters such as angular_dist_threshold and max_angular_accel.
What is the primary_controller parameter in the Rotation Shim Controller?
The primary_controller parameter is the type of controller that your application would like to use as the primary modus operandi, which shares the same name and yaml namespace as the shim plugin.
Can you include primary_controller specific parameters in the same yaml namespace as the Rotation Shim Controller?
Yes, you can include primary_controller specific parameters in the same yaml namespace as the Rotation Shim Controller.
What is the purpose of this tutorial?
To setup Visual-Inerial Odometry (VIO) into a Nav2 and ROS 2 based robotics system to augment robot odometry.
What types of robots are notorious for producing suboptimal odometry?
Skid-steer, tracked, omnidirectional robots using mecanum wheels, and legged robots.
What is the benefit of using Visual-Inerial Odometry (VIO)?

It can compute high-speed relative motion independent of robot mechanics, making it useful for UAVs without accurate intrinsic odometric sensing capabilities or mobile robots with poor intrinsic odometry measurements.
What VIO solution is used in this tutorial?
StereolabsSDK's Position Tracking capability paired with the new ZED X camera.
Why is the ZED X camera chosen for this tutorial?
Due to its ease of use and production-quality performance when using a ZED camera module.
What is the purpose of setting up the ZED ROS 2 drivers?
To publish the VIO to a topic and leave the TF tree to the fusion algorithm and Robot State Publisher.
What package is used to fuse VIO into the local state estimate?
What is the purpose of fusing VIO into the local state estimate?
To improve the quality of the state estimation required for a well-engineered system that is able to accurately and predictably complete its tasks.
What is the result of fusing the Stereolabs SDK's Pose Tracking VIO solution with a robot's external IMU and odometry?
The Visual-Inertial Odometry's error is 4.1% over the 70m path, and it improves overall performance to an acceptable level when fused with the legged robot odometry.

A motion planning method that combines heterogeneous motion planners to produce more robust or reactive solutions.
What is the general approach of Hybrid Planning?
Combining a pair of global and local planners that run in parallel and recurrently with different planning speeds and problem scopes.
What is the role of the global planner in Hybrid Planning?
To solve a global motion planning problem and provide an initial solution or iteratively optimized solutions during execution.
What is the role of the local planner in Hybrid Planning?
To produce iterative robot commands for following the global trajectory and to reason about the world and have an internal state.
What are the characteristics of the local planner?
Fast, able to react to sensor feedback, real-time safe, and deterministic.
Why is the local planner dependent on the reference trajectory produced by the global planner?
To avoid getting stuck in a local minimum.
What is the purpose of the event-based logic in Hybrid Planning?
To communicate planner events and process them accordingly, allowing for customized logic for specific use cases and planner types.
What are the three main scenarios where Hybrid Planning can be useful?
Not specified in the provided context.
What is the Hybrid Planning Architecture composed of?
Three ROS component nodes: Hybrid Planning Manager, Global Planner, and Local Planner.
What is the role of the Hybrid Planning Manager?
To process HybridPlanner action requests and coordinate the motion planning and execution process based on the planning logic plugin.
What is the role of the PlanningLogic plugin?
To implement event-driven logic that triggers actions or cancellations targeting the global or local planners.
What is the Global Planner component responsible for?
Providing an action server that processes GlobalPlanner requests and publishes the planning result and solution trajectory.
What is the plugin infrastructure used for in MoveIt?
Allowing users to write their own inverse kinematics algorithms.

What does the Allowed Collision Matrix (ACM) encode?
A binary value corresponding to the need to check for collision between pairs of bodies.
What happens if the value in the ACM is set to true for two bodies?

Why is collision detection sometimes disabled for a pair in the ACM?

What is the purpose of the Motion Planning Plugin in MoveIt?

What is the default motion planner for move_group configured using?

What is the purpose of the motion plan request?
The motion plan request specifies what you would like the motion planner to do, typically moving an arm to a different location or the end-effector to a new pose.
What is the result of the move_group node in response to a motion plan request?
A desired trajectory that moves the arm to the desired location, obeying velocity and acceleration constraints at the joint level.
What is the purpose of planning request adapters?
Planning request adapters allow for pre-processing motion plan requests and post-processing motion plan responses.
What is the function of the CheckStartStateBounds adapter?
The CheckStartStateBounds adapter fixes the start state to be within the joint limits specified in the URDF.
What is the function of the ValidateWorkspaceBounds adapter?
The ValidateWorkspaceBounds adapter specifies a default workspace for planning, a cube of size 10 m x 10 m x 10 m.
What is the function of the CheckStartStateCollision adapter?
The CheckStartStateCollision adapter attempts to sample a new collision-free configuration near a specified configuration by perturbing the joint values.
What is the function of the AddTimeParameterization adapter?
The AddTimeParameterization adapter time parameterizes the motion plans by applying velocity and acceleration constraints.
What is the function of the ResolveConstraintFrames adapter?
The ResolveConstraintFrames adapter changes the frame of constraints to an object or robot frame.
OMPL (Open Motion Planning Library) is an open-source motion planning library that primarily implements randomized motion planners.

What is the fundamental idea of MoveIt Task Constructor (MTC)?

The fundamental idea of MTC is that complex motion planning problems can be composed into a set of simpler subproblems. The top-level planning problem is specified as a Task while all subproblems are specified by Stages. Stages can be arranged in any arbitrary order and hierarchy only limited by the individual stages types.
What are the three possible stages relating to the result flow in MTC?

The three possible stages relating to the result flow in MTC are: Generators, Propagators, and Connectors. Generators compute their results independently of their neighbor stages and pass them in both directions, backwards and forwards. Propagators receive the result of one neighbor stage, solve a subproblem and then propagate their result to the neighbor on the opposite site. Connectors do not propagate any results, but rather attempt to bridge the gap between the resulting states of both neighbors.
What are the different hierarchy types in MTC?

There are three container types in MTC: Wrappers, Serial Containers, and Parallel Containers. Wrappers encapsulate a single subordinate stage and modify or filter the results. Serial Containers hold a sequence of subordinate stages and only consider end-to-end solutions as results. Parallel Containers combine set of subordinate stages and can be used for passing the best of alternative results, running fallback solvers or for merging multiple independent solutions.
What is the purpose of the setupPlanningScene function in the MTCTaskNode class?

The purpose of the setupPlanningScene function in the MTCTaskNode class is to create a planning scene that is used in the example. It creates a cylinder with dimensions specified by object.primitives[0].dimensions and position specified by pose.position.x and pose.position.y.
What is the purpose of the createTask function in the MTCTaskNode class?

The purpose of the createTask function in the MTCTaskNode class is to create a MoveIt Task Constructor object and set some initial properties. It also adds stages to the task, including a CurrentState stage, a MoveTo stage, and a ComputeIK stage.

What is the structure of the tf2 tree?
tf2 builds up a tree structure of frames and does not allow a closed loop in the frame structure. This means that a frame only has one single parent, but it can have multiple children.
What is the purpose of the fixed frame broadcaster?
The fixed frame broadcaster is used to add a new frame, carrot1, which will be the child of the turtle1 frame. This frame will serve as the goal for the second turtle.
What is the purpose of the dynamic frame broadcaster?
The dynamic frame broadcaster is used to publish a moving frame that changes relative to the parent frame over time.
How is the transform defined in the fixed frame broadcaster?
The transform is defined with a fixed offset of 2 meters in the y-axis from the parent frame, turtle1, to the new child frame, carrot1.
How is the transform defined in the dynamic frame broadcaster?
The transform is defined using the sin() and cos() functions on the current time, so that the offset of carrot1 is constantly changing.

Cross-compilation is the process of building software for a different platform than the one on which the build is being performed.
Why do developers rely on cross-compilation?

Developers rely on cross-compilation for reasons such as: the development machine does not match the target system, tuning the build for specific core architecture, and targeting a file system other than the ones supported by the pre-built images released by Open Robotics.
Cross-compiling simple software requires a cross-compiler toolchain to be used instead of the native toolchain.
What factors make cross-compilation more complex?

Factors that make cross-compilation more complex include: the software being built must support the target architecture, architecture specific code must be properly isolated and enabled during the build, and all dependencies must be present, either as pre-built or cross-compiled packages.
What is an alternative to cross-compilation?
An alternative to cross-compilation is to build multi-platform Docker images using docker buildx.
Why is it necessary to isolate and enable architecture-specific code during cross-compilation?
To ensure that the software being built supports the target architecture.
What is required for building software stacks using build tools?
The build tool must provide a mechanism to allow the developer to enable cross-compilation on the underlying build system used by each piece of software in the stack.

What is the final release preparations stage in the development process?

What is the significance of World Turtle Day in the ROS 2 development process?

A ROS distribution is a versioned set of ROS packages.
What is the purpose of the ROS distributions?
The purpose of the ROS distributions is to let developers work against a relatively stable codebase until they are ready to roll everything forward.
What is the Rolling distribution of ROS 2?
The Rolling distribution of ROS 2 is the rolling development distribution of ROS 2, serving as a staging area for future stable distributions and a collection of the most recent development releases.
How often is a new ROS 2 distribution released?
A new ROS 2 distribution is released yearly on May 23rd (World Turtle Day).
What is the difference between the Rolling distribution and stable distributions?

The Rolling distribution is continuously updated and can have in-place updates that include breaking changes, while stable distributions are recommended for most people and are updated less frequently.
What happens to packages released into the Rolling distribution?
Packages released into the Rolling distribution will be automatically released into future stable distributions of ROS 2.
What is the recommended distribution for most people?
The most recent stable distribution is recommended for most people.
